elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) supporting tunable through-framework conduction and responsive properties are of significant interest for enabling a new generation of active devices. However, such architectures are rare. We report a redox-active CP composed of two-dimensional (2D) lattices of coordinatively bonded Mo2(INA)4 clusters (INA = isonicotinate). The 2D lattices are commensurately stacked and their ordering topology can be synthetically tuned. The material has a hierarchical pore structure (pore sizes distributed between 7 and 33 Å) and exhibits unique CO2 adsorption (nominally Type VI) for an isotherm collected at 195 K. Furthermore, cyclic voltammetry and electrokinetic analyses identify a quasi-reversible feature at E 1/2 = −1.275 V versus ferrocene/ferrocenium that can be ascribed to the [Mo2(INA)4]0/–1 redox couple, with an associated standard heterogeneous electron transfer rate constant k s = 1.49 s–1. The tunable structure, porosity, and redox activity of our material may render it a promising platform for CPs with responsive properties.
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers (CPs) supporting tunable through-framework conduction and responsive properties are of significant interest for enabling a new generation of active devices. However, such architectures are rare. We report a redox-active CP composed of two-dimensional (2D) lattices of coordinatively bonded Mo2(INA)4 clusters (INA = isonicotinate). The 2D lattices are commensurately stacked and their ordering topology can be synthetically tuned. The material has a hierarchical pore structure (pore sizes distributed between 7 and 33 Å) and exhibits unique CO2 adsorption (nominally Type VI) for an isotherm collected at 195 K. Furthermore, cyclic voltammetry and electrokinetic analyses identify a quasi-reversible feature at E 1/2 = -1.275 V versus ferrocene/ferrocenium that can be ascribed to the [Mo2(INA)4]0/-1 redox couple, with an associated standard heterogeneous electron transfer rate constant k s = 1.49 s-1. The tunable structure, porosity, and redox activity of our material may render it a promising platform for CPs with responsive properties.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) are characterized by a diversity of architectures, porosities, and chemistries that collectively render them useful in gas and ion occlusion, separations, and catalysis. Recently, significant interest has focused on the development of responsive CPs that could enable a new generation of active device architectures including filters, switches, membranes, and sensors. The incorporation of redox tunable states in CPs and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) is one approach to engender a responsive framework with functional properties of scientific and technological importance. The post-synthetic incorporation of redox-active species into the pores of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has yielded impressive architectures exhibiting conductivity, enhanced structural stability, and even catalytic activity. However, despite recent progress in design of conductive frameworks, development of CPs exhibiting through-framework conduction via the redox-states of their constituent metal or ligand centers has received less attention.
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers (CPs) are characterized by a diversity of architectures, porosities, and chemistries that collectively render them useful in gas and ion occlusion, separations, and catalysis. Recently, significant interest has focused on the development of responsive CPs that could enable a new generation of active device architectures including filters, switches, membranes, and sensors. The incorporation of redox tunable states in CPs and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) is one approach to engender a responsive framework with functional properties of scientific and technological importance. The post-synthetic incorporation of redox-active species into the pores of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has yielded impressive architectures exhibiting conductivity, enhanced structural stability, and even catalytic activity. However, despite recent progress in design of conductive frameworks, development of CPs exhibiting through-framework conduction via the redox-states of their constituent metal or ligand centers has received less attention.

elements.content: We identified Mo2(INA)4 as the molecular building block for our candidate responsive CP material. This cluster is composed of a quadruply bonded dimolybdenum core (Mo2)4+ coordinated by 4 equatorial isonicotinate (INA) ligands and exhibits several features of interest. First, the two strongly coupled Mo atoms can support a delocalized Class III Robin–Day mixed-valence state. This mixed-valence Mo2 core, if coupled effectively to neighboring ligands, could support long-range through-framework charge transfer. Second, the potential to tune the redox state of this di-Mo core could render a desired responsive material. Third, the heterotopic equatorial INA ligands, and open axial coordination sites on the Mo2 core, provide synthetic versatility for assembly of various crystal topologies.
elements.clean_text: We identified Mo2(INA)4 as the molecular building block for our candidate responsive CP material. This cluster is composed of a quadruply bonded dimolybdenum core (Mo2)4+ coordinated by 4 equatorial isonicotinate (INA) ligands and exhibits several features of interest. First, the two strongly coupled Mo atoms can support a delocalized Class III Robin-Day mixed-valence state. This mixed-valence Mo2 core, if coupled effectively to neighboring ligands, could support long-range through-framework charge transfer. Second, the potential to tune the redox state of this di-Mo core could render a desired responsive material. Third, the heterotopic equatorial INA ligands, and open axial coordination sites on the Mo2 core, provide synthetic versatility for assembly of various crystal topologies.

elements.content: Our efforts take inspiration from the literature on preparation and exploration of dinuclear transition metal clusters. Previous efforts have focused on the synthesis, theoretical treatment, and electronic spectroscopy of the diatomic clusters, ions, and metal–ligand clusters of the first and second row transition metals. Within this context, research has focused on molecular complexes and cages containing Mo2 cores, and on supramolecular arrays of isolated M2 (M = Mo, Rh, Ru) dimers and polyhedra. However, to the best of our knowledge, examples of CPs composed of quadruply bonded dinuclear second row transition metal clusters are rare.
elements.clean_text: Our efforts take inspiration from the literature on preparation and exploration of dinuclear transition metal clusters. Previous efforts have focused on the synthesis, theoretical treatment, and electronic spectroscopy of the diatomic clusters, ions, and metal-ligand clusters of the first and second row transition metals. Within this context, research has focused on molecular complexes and cages containing Mo2 cores, and on supramolecular arrays of isolated M2 (M = Mo, Rh, Ru) dimers and polyhedra. However, to the best of our knowledge, examples of CPs composed of quadruply bonded dinuclear second row transition metal clusters are rare.

elements.content: We also note that despite reports, which harken back to the early 20th century, discussing the importance of mixed-valence complexes such as Prussian blue, to-date, demonstrations of coordination polymers exhibiting mixed-valence mechanisms are still rare.
elements.clean_text: We also note that despite reports, which harken back to the early 20th century, discussing the importance of mixed-valence complexes such as Prussian blue, to-date, demonstrations of coordination polymers exhibiting mixed-valence mechanisms are still rare.

elements.content: We prepared the aforementioned Mo2(INA)4 cluster through a ligand exchange reaction (). Reaction of dimolybdenum tetraacetate with 10 equiv of isonicotinic acid at 120 °C in dimethylformamide yields a bright red powder. Mass spectrometry of this powder identified a feature at 680 m/z (). This ratio corresponds to the molar mass of Mo2(INA)4, the desired molecular building block.
elements.clean_text: We prepared the aforementioned Mo2(INA)4 cluster through a ligand exchange reaction (). Reaction of dimolybdenum tetraacetate with 10 equiv of isonicotinic acid at 120 °C in dimethylformamide yields a bright red powder. Mass spectrometry of this powder identified a feature at 680 m/z (). This ratio corresponds to the molar mass of Mo2(INA)4, the desired molecular building block.

elements.content: Ligand exchange reaction yielding Mo2(INA)4.

To assemble CPs from this cluster, we performed recrystallizations from solutions containing Mo2(INA)4 and either only dimethylacetamide (DMA) or DMA and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane (DABCO). Recrystallization at room temperature over the course of 2 days yielded dark red single crystals from DMA solutions (I) and from DMA and DABCO solutions (II). Crystal structures obtained through single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments () conducted at 110 K on I (a,c) and on II (b,d) identify several salient features of the new CP frameworks. First, both paddlewheel nodes of the framework (a,b) consist of 2 bonded Mo atoms coordinated to the carboxylate groups of 4 INA ligands. Second, the Mo–Mo bond distances in I and II are 2.1211(4) and 2.1227(3) Å, respectively. These distances are within 2% of the Mo–Mo bond distances observed in quadruply bonded Mo2 cores coordinated by 3-atom bridging ligands. Third, each Mo is bonded to the pyridyl-N of the INA ligand of an adjacent node with Mo–N bond distances within I and II ranging between 2.546(3) and 2.586(3) Å. These coordination bonds give rise to a 2D lattice of Mo2(INA)4 nodes (). Finally, packing diagrams viewed down the c axis of both I and II (c,d) show that the crystals (space groups, I: P2/c and II: P21/c) are porous and composed of the 2D lattices stacked commensurately atop one another. Together, these data show successful assembly of CPs composed of Mo2(INA)4 clusters joined into a 2D lattice.
elements.clean_text: To assemble CPs from this cluster, we performed recrystallizations from solutions containing Mo2(INA)4 and either only dimethylacetamide (DMA) or DMA and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO). Recrystallization at room temperature over the course of 2 days yielded dark red single crystals from DMA solutions (I) and from DMA and DABCO solutions (II). Crystal structures obtained through single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments () conducted at 110 K on I (a,c) and on II (b,d) identify several salient features of the new CP frameworks. First, both paddlewheel nodes of the framework (a,b) consist of 2 bonded Mo atoms coordinated to the carboxylate groups of 4 INA ligands. Second, the Mo-Mo bond distances in I and II are 2.1211(4) and 2.1227(3) Å, respectively. These distances are within 2% of the Mo-Mo bond distances observed in quadruply bonded Mo2 cores coordinated by 3-atom bridging ligands. Third, each Mo is bonded to the pyridyl-N of the INA ligand of an adjacent node with Mo-N bond distances within I and II ranging between 2.546(3) and 2.586(3) Å. These coordination bonds give rise to a 2D lattice of Mo2(INA)4 nodes (). Finally, packing diagrams viewed down the c axis of both I and II (c,d) show that the crystals (space groups, I: P2/c and II: P21/c) are porous and composed of the 2D lattices stacked commensurately atop one another. Together, these data show successful assembly of CPs composed of Mo2(INA)4 clusters joined into a 2D lattice.

elements.content: (a) Crystal structure of the Mo2(INA)4 cluster used to assemble I. (b) Crystal structure of the Mo2(INA)4 cluster used to assemble II. (c) Crystal packing structure of I viewed down the c axis. (d) Crystal packing structure of II viewed down the c axis. Disorder, hydrogen atoms and lattice solvent molecules omitted for clarity. Displacement ellipsoids given at 50% probability.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Crystal structure of the Mo2(INA)4 cluster used to assemble I. (b) Crystal structure of the Mo2(INA)4 cluster used to assemble II. (c) Crystal packing structure of I viewed down the c axis. (d) Crystal packing structure of II viewed down the c axis. Disorder, hydrogen atoms and lattice solvent molecules omitted for clarity. Displacement ellipsoids given at 50% probability.

elements.content: A detailed analysis of the structures of I and II identifies several features of our 2D material that are sensitive to recrystallization conditions. The 2D (100) lattice planes of I and II are composed of slightly distorted square subcells containing 4 coordinatively bonded Mo2(INA)4 nodes (). The in-plane diagonals of these subcells are 14.015 and 12.991 Å, and 14.313 and 12.809 Å for I and II, respectively. Furthermore, whereas the (100) lattice planes in I are separated by an average interplanar spacing of 8.190 Å, those in II regularly alternate between two distinct d spacings: d 1 = 7.854 Å and d 2 = 8.565 Å (c,d). In the structure of I, the lattice DMA solvent molecules show significant disorder in their packing orientation and pore occupancy (). In the structure of II, the lattice DMA orients parallel (perpendicular) to the (100) lattice planes in the interplanar space having a thickness d 1 (d 2) (). Previously, DABCO has been integrated into MOFs as a pillaring ligand intended to organize square-grid layered structures into 3D open frameworks. Notably, crystal structures and acid digestions of bulk crystalline samples of II verify that no DABCO is present in II (). In summary, though DABCO does not integrate into II, it does appear to facilitate improved crystalline ordering and the alternate interplanar spacing between 2D lattices. We hypothesize that DABCO plays a structure-directing role by reversibly binding to Lewis acidic coordination sites with an attendant modulation of crystal packing.
elements.clean_text: A detailed analysis of the structures of I and II identifies several features of our 2D material that are sensitive to recrystallization conditions. The 2D (100) lattice planes of I and II are composed of slightly distorted square subcells containing 4 coordinatively bonded Mo2(INA)4 nodes (). The in-plane diagonals of these subcells are 14.015 and 12.991 Å, and 14.313 and 12.809 Å for I and II, respectively. Furthermore, whereas the (100) lattice planes in I are separated by an average interplanar spacing of 8.190 Å, those in II regularly alternate between two distinct d spacings: d 1 = 7.854 Å and d 2 = 8.565 Å (c,d). In the structure of I, the lattice DMA solvent molecules show significant disorder in their packing orientation and pore occupancy (). In the structure of II, the lattice DMA orients parallel (perpendicular) to the (100) lattice planes in the interplanar space having a thickness d 1 (d 2) (). Previously, DABCO has been integrated into MOFs as a pillaring ligand intended to organize square-grid layered structures into 3D open frameworks. Notably, crystal structures and acid digestions of bulk crystalline samples of II verify that no DABCO is present in II (). In summary, though DABCO does not integrate into II, it does appear to facilitate improved crystalline ordering and the alternate interplanar spacing between 2D lattices. We hypothesize that DABCO plays a structure-directing role by reversibly binding to Lewis acidic coordination sites with an attendant modulation of crystal packing.

elements.content: Having established the long-range crystalline order of 2D CPs prepared from Mo2(INA)4 precursor, we set out to assess their porous characteristics through Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis. BET analysis of CO2 adsorption and desorption for isotherms collected at 195 K on I reveals several unique features (a,b). Adsorption data exhibit three distinct regions (A, 0–0.3 p/p 0; B, 0.3–0.5 p/p 0; C, 0.5–0.9 p/p 0) and can be broadly classified as belonging to a Type VI isotherm. Only two distinct transitions are observed within the desorption data, and there is a significant hysteresis loop between adsorption and desorption data. Notably, N2 adsorption and desorption data collected on I are characteristic of a Type III isotherm (), which is associated with weak adsorbate–adsorbent interactions. These data emphasize that I undergoes a unique interaction with CO2, as compared to N2. Furthermore, though the stepwise profile of the CO2 isotherm suggests layer-by-layer filling of a range of pores via capillary condensation, we cannot rule out that strong interaction of CO2 with I may induce structural transformation of the framework and result in increased CO2 uptake at higher relative pressures. We note that calculation of pore surface areas for complex isotherms that exhibit a number of distinct features is not trivial. Nevertheless, specific BET and Langmuir pore surface areas calculated from the adsorption isotherm within the 0.05–0.3 p/p 0 region (b) and at saturation (0.95 p/p 0) are 18.6 and 505.1 m2/g, respectively (). Notably, pXRD data of I taken after BET analysis show that the crystal structure of I is well retained ().
elements.clean_text: Having established the long-range crystalline order of 2D CPs prepared from Mo2(INA)4 precursor, we set out to assess their porous characteristics through Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis. BET analysis of CO2 adsorption and desorption for isotherms collected at 195 K on I reveals several unique features (a,b). Adsorption data exhibit three distinct regions (A, 0-0.3 p/p 0; B, 0.3-0.5 p/p 0; C, 0.5-0.9 p/p 0) and can be broadly classified as belonging to a Type VI isotherm. Only two distinct transitions are observed within the desorption data, and there is a significant hysteresis loop between adsorption and desorption data. Notably, N2 adsorption and desorption data collected on I are characteristic of a Type III isotherm (), which is associated with weak adsorbate-adsorbent interactions. These data emphasize that I undergoes a unique interaction with CO2, as compared to N2. Furthermore, though the stepwise profile of the CO2 isotherm suggests layer-by-layer filling of a range of pores via capillary condensation, we cannot rule out that strong interaction of CO2 with I may induce structural transformation of the framework and result in increased CO2 uptake at higher relative pressures. We note that calculation of pore surface areas for complex isotherms that exhibit a number of distinct features is not trivial. Nevertheless, specific BET and Langmuir pore surface areas calculated from the adsorption isotherm within the 0.05-0.3 p/p 0 region (b) and at saturation (0.95 p/p 0) are 18.6 and 505.1 m2/g, respectively (). Notably, pXRD data of I taken after BET analysis show that the crystal structure of I is well retained ().

elements.content: (a) Adsorption and desorption portions of the CO2 isotherm collected at 195 K on I. (b) Expanded view of the CO2 adsorption isotherm in the 0–0.3 p/p 0 region. (c) Differential pore volume (dV/dw) data identifying pore sizes in I.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Adsorption and desorption portions of the CO2 isotherm collected at 195 K on I. (b) Expanded view of the CO2 adsorption isotherm in the 0-0.3 p/p 0 region. (c) Differential pore volume (dV/dw) data identifying pore sizes in I.

elements.content: A plot of differential pore volume as a function of pore width was obtained through analysis of adsorption data with the Horvath–Kawazoe model (c). The pore distribution data identify two narrow peaks associated with pore widths of 7 and 10 Å, and two broad peaks associated with pore widths of 20 and 33 Å. The former 2 peaks can be associated with CO2 uptake by the ∼13–14 Å pores formed by the square subcells comprising the 2D planes of I (), whereas the latter 2 peaks may be associated with CO2 uptake by pores in the interplanar space between 2D lattices. Integration of the differential pore width data shows that 84% of the total adsorbed CO2 is sequestered by pores >20 Å in width. The unique CO2 uptake properties of I are potentially a consequence of its hierarchical structure. In particular, it is possible that the crystal expands about the interplanar space to accommodate more CO2 storage at higher relative pressures. We note that the gas uptake properties reported herein are distinct from those reported in other layered 2D CPs and 3D CPs.
elements.clean_text: A plot of differential pore volume as a function of pore width was obtained through analysis of adsorption data with the Horvath-Kawazoe model (c). The pore distribution data identify two narrow peaks associated with pore widths of 7 and 10 Å, and two broad peaks associated with pore widths of 20 and 33 Å. The former 2 peaks can be associated with CO2 uptake by the ~13-14 Å pores formed by the square subcells comprising the 2D planes of I (), whereas the latter 2 peaks may be associated with CO2 uptake by pores in the interplanar space between 2D lattices. Integration of the differential pore width data shows that 84% of the total adsorbed CO2 is sequestered by pores >20 Å in width. The unique CO2 uptake properties of I are potentially a consequence of its hierarchical structure. In particular, it is possible that the crystal expands about the interplanar space to accommodate more CO2 storage at higher relative pressures. We note that the gas uptake properties reported herein are distinct from those reported in other layered 2D CPs and 3D CPs.

elements.content: Finally, we set out to assess whether our CPs have readily accessible redox states, which could mediate through-framework charge transfer and enable the use of these materials in future electronic devices. To this end, the redox properties of I were assessed through cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrokinetic analysis of CV data taken at multiple scan rates. CV data of I taken at a scan rate (ν) of 50 mV/s in acetonitrile, 0.1 M tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBA PF6), and 20 mM 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (BMIM BF4) identify several features (a). First, a small anodic wave is apparent between −100 and +100 mV vs the Fc/Fc+ redox couple (a, inset). Previously reported CV data of molecular dimers of quadruply bonded di-Mo clusters have identified oxidation waves at −90 and +100 mV relative to Fc/Fc+ that were attributed to [(tBuCO2)3Mo2]2(μ-O2C–C10H6–CO2)0/+1 and [(tBuCO2)3Mo2]2(μ-O2C–C6F4–CO2)0/+1 couples, respectively. Therefore, we associate the modest anodic peak between −100 and +100 mV in CVs of I with the [Mo2(INA)4]0/+1 couple.
elements.clean_text: Finally, we set out to assess whether our CPs have readily accessible redox states, which could mediate through-framework charge transfer and enable the use of these materials in future electronic devices. To this end, the redox properties of I were assessed through cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrokinetic analysis of CV data taken at multiple scan rates. CV data of I taken at a scan rate (ν) of 50 mV/s in acetonitrile, 0.1 M tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBA PF6), and 20 mM 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (BMIM BF4) identify several features (a). First, a small anodic wave is apparent between -100 and +100 mV vs the Fc/Fc+ redox couple (a, inset). Previously reported CV data of molecular dimers of quadruply bonded di-Mo clusters have identified oxidation waves at -90 and +100 mV relative to Fc/Fc+ that were attributed to [(tBuCO2)3Mo2]2(μ-O2C-C10H6-CO2)0/+1 and [(tBuCO2)3Mo2]2(μ-O2C-C6F4-CO2)0/+1 couples, respectively. Therefore, we associate the modest anodic peak between -100 and +100 mV in CVs of I with the [Mo2(INA)4]0/+1 couple.

elements.content: (a) CV of I in acetonitrile, TBA PF6, and BMIM BF4 collected at a scan rate of 50 mV/s. Inset: Expanded view of anodic wave in CV of I at ν = 5 mV/s. (b) Trumpet plot assembled from data of cathodic (E pc) and anodic (E pa) peak potentials as a function of scan rate (Figure S9).
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) CV of I in acetonitrile, TBA PF6, and BMIM BF4 collected at a scan rate of 50 mV/s. Inset: Expanded view of anodic wave in CV of I at ν = 5 mV/s. (b) Trumpet plot assembled from data of cathodic (E pc) and anodic (E pa) peak potentials as a function of scan rate (Figure S9).

elements.content: Second, a quasi-reversible (i pa/i pc = 0.26) redox wave with E 1/2 = −1.275 V is apparent, and multiple CV scans taken at ν = 50 mV/s show retention of this redox wave (). The cathodic and anodic peak potentials associated with this feature are E pc = −1.32 V and E pa = −1.23 V, respectively, and their separation implies a 1 electron process. We note that reduction of a range of isonicotinates was previously reported to occur at −2.2 V versus Ag/Ag+ (∼ −2.6 V vs Fc/Fc+), which is well outside of our scanned potential range. We consequently rule out the possibility that cathodic features in our reported CVs of I are due to reduction of INA ligand. Therefore, we assign the cathodic peak at −1.32 V to 1 electron reduction and associate the redox wave at E 1/2 = −1.275 V with the [Mo2(INA)4]0/–1 couple. A subsequent electrokinetic analysis was used to determine the rate of electron transfer associated with this couple. CVs of I were collected at scan rates between 5 and 200 mV/s (). These data show an increase, as a function of increasing scan rate, in the splitting of the cathodic and anodic peak potentials associated with this couple. This observation is consistent with the onset of electrochemical irreversibility as the electrode reaction becomes dominated by the kinetics of electron transfer at the electrode. Using these data, a plot of the difference between the cathodic or anodic peak potential and the midpoint potential for the couple versus the logarithm of the scan rate was prepared (b). A Laviron analysis of these data furnishes an apparent heterogeneous electron transfer (ET) rate constant k s = 1.49 s–1 for the [Mo2(INA)4]0/–1 couple, assuming a 1 electron process and a transfer coefficient α = 0.5 ().

The cathodic and anodic peak potentials associated with this feature are E pc = -1.32 V and E pa = -1.23 V, respectively, and their separation implies a 1 electron process. We note that reduction of a range of isonicotinates was previously reported to occur at -2.2 V versus Ag/Ag+ (~ -2.6 V vs Fc/Fc+), which is well outside of our scanned potential range. We consequently rule out the possibility that cathodic features in our reported CVs of I are due to reduction of INA ligand. Therefore, we assign the cathodic peak at -1.32 V to 1 electron reduction and associate the redox wave at E 1/2 = -1.275 V with the [Mo2(INA)4]0/-1 couple. A subsequent electrokinetic analysis was used to determine the rate of electron transfer associated with this couple. CVs of I were collected at scan rates between 5 and 200 mV/s (). These data show an increase, as a function of increasing scan rate, in the splitting of the cathodic and anodic peak potentials associated with this couple. This observation is consistent with the onset of electrochemical irreversibility as the electrode reaction becomes dominated by the kinetics of electron transfer at the electrode. Using these data, a plot of the difference between the cathodic or anodic peak potential and the midpoint potential for the couple versus the logarithm of the scan rate was prepared (b). A Laviron analysis of these data furnishes an apparent heterogeneous electron transfer (ET) rate constant k s = 1.49 s-1 for the [Mo2(INA)4]0/-1 couple, assuming a 1 electron process and a transfer coefficient α = 0.5 ().

elements.content:
In conclusion, we have demonstrated a redox-active and porous CP composed of 2D lattices assembled from Mo2(INA)4 clusters.

The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/jacs.8b06331.

metadata.title:
Hierarchically
Ordered Two-Dimensional Coordination
Polymers Assembled from Redox-Active Dimolybdenum Clusters
